In a perfectly competitive market, a firm will continue to expand production until
marginal revenue (MR) equals marginal cost (MC). Marginal revenue is the increase in
total revenue from selling one more unit of a good or service. For a price taker, marginal
revenue is simply the price because all additional units are assumed to be sold at the
same (market) price. In pure competition, a firm's marginal revenue is equal to the market
price, and a firm's MR curve, presented in Figure 3, is identical to its demand curve. A
profit maximizing firm will produce the quantity, Q“, when MC = MR.
